messageBody:
On 31/07/07, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
> It's reasonable to want only one of an object, but for me it comes down
> to one question: can I trust my team members not to create two? If I
> can, it makes sense to avoid the singleton. The enforcement that
> singleton brings is the solution to a problem, but the problem is social
> not technical. It pays to know whether you have the problem or not.

Nicely put.

And, may I add, that a technical solution to social problem is a poor
substitute for a social solution to the social problem.

If members of the team don't understand the architecture then tech
huddles and a big visible architecture diagram can help.

If the class names don't express the idea that there should only be
one of a class in the production code then a tech huddle to agree on a
system of names and a refactoring session can help.

If team members don't know how to manage dependencies between objects
then arrange for some training and/or mentoring.

Etc., etc.

--Nat
